Award.AwardTitle: Research: Researching the Value of Educator Actions for Learning (REVEAL)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This three-year research project will study the impact of science center staff facilitation strategies in the area of mathematics learning in a museum exhibit environment. The three main deliverables are:
1) Iteratively developing and refining a theoretical model of how staff facilitation can deepen and extend family mathematical discourse at interactive exhibits.
2) Rigorously testing key components of this model, including the relationship between staff facilitation and the nature of family mathematical discourse.
3) Providing evidence and research-based tools to support PD efforts for informal STEM educators.

The project will leverage the success of the NSF-funded Access Algebra project (DRL-0714634) to advance the field's understanding of socially mediated, informal math learning and identify effective, evidence-based facilitation approaches. The project's research will build from theoretical notion of sociomathematical norms (Yackel & Cobb, 1996), which is currently based on classroom research. A key element of the project will be to determine whether and how, the norms can be applied to informal learning environments.

The first phase of the project begins with a qualitative, design-based research (DBR) study to develop a theoretical model of staff-facilitated family math learning, including staff facilitation strategies that support family mathematical discourse and contextual factors that influence that discourse. In the second phase of the project, the team will use an experimental approach to rigorously test the staff facilitation model developed during Phase 1. This mixed-method design will allow the team to both study the complexities of informal math learning and rigorously test causal connections between staff facilitation and the level of family math discourse. Finally, the project staff will provide tools to support PD efforts for informal STEM educators across the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of Researching the Value of Educator Actions for Learning (REVEAL) was to learn more about the roles of informal educators at interactive math exhibits in science centers and to create and share research-based professional development tools for exhibit facilitation. Built on the Design Zone exhibition, which highlights the relationship between mathematical thinking and the creative process, this research is intended to help science center facilitators support deeper and longer family math learning interactions at exhibits, contributing to a larger impact on mathematical reasoning skills among the nation’s public. While developed within the context of mathematics-based exhibits, the knowledge and professional development tools resulting from REVEAL are relevant for the broader community of informal science educators.

Working with a research advisory committee, staff from the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, TERC, Oregon State University, Institute for Learning Innovation, and Adelante Mujeres collaborated on five studies between Fall 2013 and Spring 2018. The quantitative and qualitative studies incorporated culturally-responsive approaches, including bilingual (Spanish/English) research staff and exhibit text. Collectively, the studies generated evidence to 1) create a research-based model of facilitation at interactive math exhibits; 2) suggest causal connections between facilitator support and family experience outcomes, such as mathematical reasoning; 3) explore possible factors influencing the relationships between facilitation and family outcomes; and 4) provide professional development resources to support facilitation at math exhibits. The outcomes are described below.

The facilitation model developed during REVEAL (see image) was created by observing and interviewing expert facilitators and documenting their techniques. The model describes a responsive facilitation cycle used to support visitor goals (observe, support, reflect), the factors that seem to influence visitor interactions (social, personal, physical), and families' exhibit experience outcomes (satisfaction, mathematical reasoning, and intergenerational communication).

The project team tested relationships in this model using a quasi-experimental study design and developed a coding scheme and instruments to measure mathematical reasoning and intergenerational communication. Analysis was conducted on over 350 video-recordings of family interactions at three different math exhibits, concluding that the levels of mathematical reasoning and general visitor satisfaction were higher with REVEAL facilitation than without facilitation.

REVEAL studies also explored influencing factors on the relationships between facilitation and family experience outcomes. One study found evidence that at least three types of events can influence a families’ shift toward deeper and longer engagement with the exhibit: when someone introduces an explicit challenge, when there is a change in the social or power dynamics of the group, and when there is a change in family members' shared understanding of the activity. A subsequent study took a closer look at the nuances of the family members’ shared understanding of the activity. Specifically, this study resulted in names for six types of emergent, shared understandings among family members about what they should be doing, how they should be doing it, and the sorts of behaviors and talk that are acceptable: completing the activity, refining actions, teaching, exploring, competing, and collaborating.

The REVEAL project team generated relevant knowledge for practitioners by asking science center facilitators to help lead the research, community educators to observe videos, and educators at a second science museum to test the REVEAL professional development program. The REVEAL studies resulted in research reports, journal publications, conference presentations, a workshop for regional educators who work specifically with members of Latino communities, and a video-based professional development program available at no cost to professionals interested in learning the research-based REVEAL facilitation methods. More information about the project, including research findings, data collection and analysis tools, and professional development resources for educators, can be found and downloaded for free at the project website: REVEAL.TERC.edu.
